Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: I stared at the stack of medical supply boxes in the back of my van, the hospital’s address scrawled in bold letters. The dispatcher’s voice echoed in my mind: “This delivery is urgent—patients are waiting.” I checked my watch, calculating the route, knowing every minute mattered. But my phone buzzed again, this time with a message from Sister Agnes: “The mayor needs us. The hurricane’s aftermath is worse than we thought. Can you help organize the relief center?” My heart twisted. As a nun, I was expected to be there for the suffering, to lead with compassion, especially now when so many had lost everything. Yet as a delivery person, I was entrusted with the lives of patients who depended on these supplies. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of both uniforms pressing on my shoulders. The van’s engine idled, and I gripped the steering wheel, torn between the hospital’s urgent need and the desperate faces of my community.
